1 JULY: 1 JULY BIBLE LESSON 1 Samuel 17:12, 14 LESSON David the Ephrathite VERSE 12 Now David was the son of that Exphrathite of Bethlehemjudah, whose name was Jesse, and he had eight sons: and the man went among men for an old man in the days of Saul. Earlier, David had been hand-picked by God to succeed king Saul. The One Who is all- knowing and all-seeing cannot be wrong in His choice. He knows the thoughts and heart of every man. On the other hand, the venerable prophet Samuel made a big mistake when he eyed the strongest looking as the most likely candidate for the royal position. David lived with his father Jesse and his seven brothers in Bethlehem [1 Samuel 16:1, 4]. They are described as Ephrathites. They are descendants of Ephrath, who lived in or around the city of Bethlehem [Genesis 48:7]. The people from Ephrath (or Ephrathah) were usually associated with Bethlehem which lies just south of Jerusalem. One person who is also linked to this place was Ruth the Moabitess who became an Ephrathite. But the most important connection of all is the famous prophecy concerning the coming Messiah's birthplace recorded in Micah 5:2, "But thou, Bethlehem Ephratah, though thou be little among the thousands of Judah, yet out of thee shall he come forth unto me that is to be ruler in Israel; whose goings forth have been from of old, from everlasting." The Messiah would be born among the Ephrathites in Bethlehem and so the Lord Jesus Christ was born in Bethlehem fulfilling this prophecy [Luke 2:4-7]. It is a humbling thought that the anointed Son of God came in such lowly fashion for the sole purpose of redeeming His people from the tyranny of the devil. But upon accomplishing His earthly mission, He ascended to be highly exalted and seated at His Father's right hand! Given the opportunity, David did not use providence or his men's urgings as excuses to take a life. Instead he stood firm doing what he knew was right - giving reverence to the LORD and His anointed. In contrast, Saul was not so much misled by his men's lies, as by the harbouring of evil in his heart because he was jealous of David. Using his men's lies as an excuse, he relentlessly pursued David to kill him. So strong was his evil desire that he diverted three thousand of his best soldiers in the midst of the war with the Philistines to hunt David [v. 2]. Our Lord Jesus taught us that obeying God begins with the heart [Matthew 5:21-32]. Do your actions reflect the integrity of your heart or do you find excuses to cover up your motives? May the Lord help us to walk close to Him with integrity of heart.
